book_title: Venture Deals: Be Smarter Than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist (Third Edition)
overall_summary:
Venture Deals is a practical, experience-driven guide to understanding and negotiating venture capital financings. The authors demystify the opaque language and processes of the venture ecosystem by explaining who the players are, why they behave the way they do, and how typical transactions are structured. From the opening historical anecdotes that show how term sheets evolved to the step-by-step breakdown of modern term-sheet clauses, the book focuses on the two core negotiation axes every deal pivots on: economics (who owns what) and control (who gets to decide).

The book first maps the ecosystem—entrepreneurs, VC firm structures (GPs, LPs, investment committees), angels, syndicates, lawyers, and advisors—so readers can see who shows up at each stage and why. It then walks through the art of the term sheet, giving a high-level overview and a clause-by-clause tour that covers pricing, option pools, liquidation preferences, anti-dilution, board composition, protective provisions, vesting, registration and information rights, pay-to-play, and other provisions that materially affect outcomes. Interspersed entrepreneur-sidebars translate lawyerly detail into founder priorities and red flags (for example, the no-shop problem and the practical handling of information rights).

Beyond priced equity, the book examines convertible instruments (notes, SAFEs/KISS), their discounts, caps, maturity mechanics, and the pitfalls of leaving debt on the cap table. It emphasizes cap-table math, showing how pre- and post-money calculations and option-pool sizing change real ownership and incentives. Crucial legal issues—employment, entity choice (C corp vs S corp vs LLC), and the time-sensitive 83(b) tax election—are highlighted as often-overlooked items that can make or break future financings and exits.

Finally, Venture Deals expands its lens to the broader ecosystem: how startup clusters form and why community matters (the Boulder Thesis). Throughout, the book is practical: it teaches entrepreneurs how to run process, create competition, pick investors, and use simple negotiation heuristics—focus on economics and control, get the right counsel, and keep the cap table clean—so readers leave with both conceptual understanding and usable tactics.
key_themes: Economics vs. control are the central levers in every venture deal
Transparency and education reduce information asymmetry between founders and investors
Practical, clause-level knowledge matters more than legal jargon
Founders must own cap-table math and long-term operational commitments
Choice of financing instrument changes incentives and future negotiation dynamics
Local entrepreneurial ecosystems and long-term community building matter for success
learning_objectives: Identify the key players in the venture ecosystem and their motivations
Read and negotiate a term sheet with focus on the economic and control consequences
Model capitalization tables to measure dilution and impact of option pools, rounds, and convertible instruments
Understand convertible debt/SAFE mechanics and when to use them versus priced rounds
Recognize common legal pitfalls (employment, entity choice, 83(b)) and how to prepare for due diligence
Apply practical negotiation tactics: manage process, create competitive tension, and use experienced counsel
Appreciate the role of community and ecosystem building in enabling startup success

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Foreword

remember the first week of my career as a VC. I was 25 years
old, it was 1986, and I had just landed a summer job in a venture
capital firm. I was working for three experienced venture capitalists
in a small firm called Euclid Partners, where I ended up spending
the first 10 years of my VC career. One of those three partners,
Bliss McCrum, peeked his head into my office (I had an office in
Rockefeller Center at age 25) and said to me, "Can you model out
a financing for XYZ Company at a $9 million pre-money, raising
$3 million, with an unissued option pool of 10%?" and then went
back to the big office in the rear he shared with the other founding
partner, Milton Pappas.

I sat at my desk and started thinking about the request. I
understood the "raising $3 million" bit. I thought I could figure
out the "unissued option pool of 10%" bit. But what the hell was
"pre-money"? I had never heard that term. This was almost a decade
before Netscape and Internet search so searching online for it wasn't
an option. After spending ten minutes getting up the courage, I
walked back to that big office, peeked my head in, and said to Bliss,
"Can you explain pre-money to me?"

Thus began my 31-year education in venture capital that is still
going on as I write this.

The venture capital business was a cottage industry back in 1985,
with club deals and a language all of its own. A cynic would say it was
designed this way to be opaque to everyone other than the VCs so that
they would have all the leverage in negotiations with entrepreneurs.
I don't entirely buy that narrative. I think the VC business grew up in
a few small offices in Boston, New York, and San Francisco, and the
dozens-maybe as many as a hundred-of main participants, along

<!-- PageNumber="xiii" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="xiv Foreword" -->

with their lawyers, came up with structures that made sense to them.
They then developed a shorthand so that they could communicate
among themselves.

But whatever the origin story was, the language of venture deals
is foreign to many and remains opaque and confusing to this day.
This works to the advantage of industry insiders and to the disadvan-
tage of those who are new to startups and venture capital.

In the early 2000s, after I wound down my first venture capital
firm, Flatiron Partners, and before we started USV, I started blogging.
One of my goals with my AVC blog (at www.avc.com) was to bring
transparency to this opaque world that I had been inhabiting for
almost 20 years. I was joined in this blogging thing by Brad Feld, a
friend and frequent coinvestor. Club investing has not gone away
and that's a good thing. By reading AVC and Feld Thoughts regu-
larly, an entrepreneur could get up to speed on startups and venture
capital. Brad and I received a tremendous amount of positive feed-
back on our efforts to bring transparency to the venture capital busi-
ness so we kept doing it, and now if you search for something like
"participating preferred" you will find posts written by both me and
Brad on that first search results page.

Brad and his partner Jason Mendelson (a recovering startup law-
yer turned VC) took things a step further and wrote a book called
Venture Deals back in 2011. It has turned into a classic and is now on
its Third Edition. If Venture Deals had been around in 1985, I would
not have had to admit to Bliss that I had no idea what pre-money
meant.

If there is a guidebook to navigating the mysterious and confusing
language of venture capital and venture capital financing structures,
it is Venture Deals. Anyone interested in startups, entrepreneurship,
and angel and venture capital financings should do themselves a
favor and read it.

Fred Wilson
USV Partner
July 2016

chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter combines a foreword and a preface that set the tone and scope for the book. The foreword (by Fred Wilson) opens with a personal anecdote about learning what “pre‑money” meant, illustrating how opaque venture capital language and deal shorthand have historically been to outsiders. It emphasizes the benefit of transparency — exemplified by blogs like AVC and Feld Thoughts — and endorses Venture Deals as a practical guide for entrepreneurs and investors alike. The preface then explains the authors’ motivation (to demystify VC term sheets), their experience across many financings, and the intended audience: entrepreneurs, angel investors, and new VCs. It outlines the book’s structure, previewing chapters on players, the fundraising process, detailed term‑sheet anatomy (economics, control, and miscellaneous terms), convertible debt, crowdfunding, how VC funds operate, negotiation tactics, stage‑specific issues, letters of intent for acquisitions, and common legal pitfalls. The authors also note the inclusion of entrepreneurial sidebars to provide complementary perspectives.

Together these sections position the book as a practical, balanced, and experience‑driven roadmap designed to make the language and mechanics of venture investing accessible. The preface highlights that there is no standard VC financing and promises context on incentives and negotiation strategies so readers can understand not just the terms but why they exist and how they affect relationships after investment. The inclusion of crowdfunding and an explicit discussion of VC firm incentives signals an expansion beyond classic term‑sheet detail to the broader ecosystem and the forces that shape deal outcomes.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet

0
ne of the first famous venture capital investments was Digital
Equipment Corporation (DEC). In 1957, American Research and
Development Corporation (AR&D), one of the first venture capital
firms, invested $70,000 in DEC. When DEC went public in 1968, this
investment was worth over $355 million, or a return of over 5,000
times the invested capital. AR&D's investment in DEC was one of the
original venture capital home runs.

In 1957, the venture capital industry was just being created. At the
time, the investor community in the United States was uninterested
in investing in computer companies, as the last wave of computer-
related startups had performed poorly and even large companies
were having difficulty making money in the computer business. We
can envision the frustration of DEC's cofounders, Ken Olson and
Harlan Anderson, as the investors they talked to rejected them
and their fledgling idea for a business. We can also imagine their
joy when Georges Doriot, the founder of American Research and
Development Corporation, offered to fund them. After a number
of conversations and meetings, Doriot sent Olson and Anderson a
letter expressing his interest in investing, along with his proposed
terms. Today, this document is called the term sheet.

Now, imagine what that term sheet looked like. There are three
different possibilities. The first is that it was a typed one-page let-
ter that said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your company
and buy 78 percent of it." The next is that it was two pages of legal
terms that basically said, "We would like to invest $70,000 in your
company and buy 78 percent of it." Or it could have been an eight-
page typed document that had all kinds of protective provisions, vesting

<!-- PageNumber="1" -->
<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="2" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals" -->

arrangements, drag-along rights, and Securities and Exchange Com-
mission (SEC) registration rights.

Our guess is that it was not the third option. Over the past 50
years, the art of the term sheet has evolved and expanded, reaching
its current eight (or so) page literary masterpiece. These eight pages
contain a lot more than "We'd like to invest $X in your company
and get Y% of it," but, as you'll learn, there really are only two key
things that matter in the actual term sheet negotiation-economics
and control.

In DEC's case, by owning 78% of the company, AR&D effec-
tively had control of the company. And the price was clearly
defined-$70,000 bought 78% of the company, resulting in a $90,000
post-money valuation.

Today's venture capital investments have many more nuances.
Individual venture capitalists (VCs) usually end up owning less than
50 percent of the company, so they don't have effective voting con-
trol but often negotiate provisions that give them control over major
decisions by the company. Many companies end up with multiple
venture capitalists who invest in the company at different points in
time, resulting in different ownership percentages, varying rights,
and diverging motivations. Founders don't always stay with the com-
pany through the exit and, in some cases, they end up leaving rela-
tively early in the life of a company for a variety of reasons. Compa-
nies fail, so venture capitalists have gotten much more focused on
protecting themselves for the downside as well as participating in the
upside. Governance issues are always complex, especially when you
have a lot of people sitting around the negotiating table.

While it would be desirable to do venture capital deals with a
simple agreement on price, a handshake, and a short legal agree-
ment, this rarely happens. And while there have been plenty of
attempts to standardize the term sheet over the years, the prolifera-
tion of lawyers, venture capitalists, and entrepreneurs, along with a
steadily increasing number of investments, has prevented this from
happening. Ironically, the actual definitive documents have become
more standard over time. Whether it is the Internet age that has
spread information across the ecosystem or clients growing tired of
paying legal bills, there are more similarities in the documents today
than ever before. As a result, we can lend you our experience in how
venture financings are usually done. The good news is once you've

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageNumber="3" -->
<!-- PageHeader="Introduction: The Art of the Term Sheet" -->

negotiated the term sheet, you are done with the hard part. As a
result, that's where we are going to focus our energy in this book.

Throughout this book we will cover not only the what and the
how, but also the why things work as they do. Let's begin our explora-
tion of venture capital financings by discussing the various players
involved.

<!-- PageFooter="www.itdf.ir" -->
<!-- PageBreak -->

<!-- PageHeader="Venture Deals: Be Smarter than Your Lawyer and Venture Capitalist, Third Edition By Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson Copyright @ 2016 by Brad Feld and Jason Mendelson" -->
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 4 introduces the reader to "the art of the term sheet," using the DEC/AR&D story to show how simple early deals evolved into today’s multi‑page term sheets. The authors emphasize that despite length and lawyerly detail, two issues dominate every negotiation: economics (who owns what) and control (who makes the decisions). The chapter explains why term sheets grew more complex — multiple rounds, multiple investors, divergent incentives, and the need to protect against downside — and why negotiating the term sheet is the hard part of a financing (after which the definitive documents are usually routine).

Building on the cast of characters introduced earlier, the chapter then profiles the participants who matter in any financing: the internal hierarchy inside VC firms (MDs/GPs, partners, principals, associates, analysts, operating partners, EIRs), angel investors and their variants (super angels, micro VCs), syndicates and lead investors, and lawyers. It gives practical fundraising guidance — executive summaries, demos, PPMs (and when they are wasteful), how VCs perform diligence, how to find and choose VCs, and tactical advice on timing and creating competition — and repeatedly returns to the negotiating mantra: focus on economics and control, use experienced counsel, and manage process and relationships carefully.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Overview of the Term Sheet

A
t the end of 2005, during the dark ages when venture capital was
very much out of favor, we participated in a financing that was much
more difficult than it needed to be. All of the participants were to
blame, and ignorance of what really mattered in the negotiation
kept things going much longer than was necessary. We talked about
what to do and, at the risk of giving away super-top-secret venture
capital magic tricks, decided to write a blog series on Brad's blog
(Feld Thoughts-www.feld.com) that deconstructed a venture capital
term sheet and explained each section.

That blog series was the inspiration for this book. The next few
chapters cover the most frequently discussed terms in a venture capi-
tal term sheet. Many venture capitalists (VCs) love to negotiate hard
on every term as though the health of their children depended on
them getting the terms just right. Sometimes this is inexperience on
the part of the VC; often, it's just a negotiating tactic.

The specific language that we refer to is from actual term sheets.
In addition to describing and explaining the specific terms, we give
you examples of what to focus on and implications from the perspec-
tives of the company, VCs, and entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 5 follows the book's earlier orientation (the opaque language and negotiating theater introduced in the foreword and preface and the ‘‘art of the term sheet’’ discussion in Chapter 4) by giving a wide‑angle tour of the typical term sheet. It emphasizes the central organizing principle introduced earlier: VCs focus on two things—economics (how returns are allocated) and control (how decision rights and vetoes are implemented). Rather than treating valuation as the sole economic lever, the chapter dissects the package of economic terms that materially affect outcomes: price, option pool sizing, warrants and bridge financings, liquidation preferences and participation, pay‑to‑play, vesting and exercise periods, antidilution mechanics, dividends, and redemption rights. For control it reviews board composition, observers, protective provisions, conversion mechanics (including automatic conversion thresholds), and the practical interaction between investor classes during follow‑on rounds.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Insist on spelling out key terms prior to a signed term sheet if it has a no-shop
clause in it. A VC who won't spell out key employment terms at the beginning
is a big red flag.

There are plenty of other wacky conditions-if you can dream it
up, it has probably been done. Just make sure to look carefully at this
paragraph and remember that you don't necessarily have a deal just
because you've signed a term sheet.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter shifts the focus from the anatomy of term sheets (Chapter 4) and the clause-by-clause tour (Chapter 5) to the entrepreneur’s vantage point and a practical warning about process and timing. The single most important takeaway is procedural: if a term sheet contains a no‑shop (exclusivity) clause, insist that key commercial and employment terms be spelled out before you sign. Because a no‑shop cuts off your bargaining leverage, signing it without having clear, agreed language on founder roles, compensation, vesting, and other vital employment items can leave you locked in while essential details remain undecided. A VC who refuses to put those basics in writing up front is a red flag.

The chapter also reminds entrepreneurs to read the less interesting boilerplate carefully — particularly the paragraph that packages odd or bespoke conditions. If you can imagine it, someone has probably tried to put it into a term sheet; don’t assume a signed term sheet equals a closed deal. In short, prioritize clarifying the few non‑economic, day‑to‑day terms that determine whether the company will actually function post‑investment, resist being boxed in by exclusivity before those items are resolved, and treat the term sheet as a step in the negotiation, not its conclusion.
key_concepts: term sheet as a step, not a final deal
main_topics: insisting on spelled‑out employment terms
risks of signing exclusivity early
reading and understanding boilerplate
negotiation leverage and timing
recognizing worrying VC tactics

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you care about information rights for your shareholders, you are nuts. You
should run a transparent organization as much as possible in the twenty-first
century. If you can't commit to sending your shareholders a budget and financial
statements, you shouldn't take on outside investors. If you are of the paranoid
mindset (which I generally applaud), feel free to insist on a strict confidentiality
clause to accompany your information rights.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 7 turns the lens from term‑sheet mechanics to the founder’s seat at the table. Building on the prior chapters’ anatomy of term sheets and clause tradeoffs, the chapter argues that information rights are not merely a lawyerly checkbox to be grudgingly accepted: they are a choice about how you will run the company after taking outside capital. The pragmatic prescription is clear — run as transparent an organization as you can afford. If you are unwilling to commit to sharing a budget and regular financial statements with your investors, you should reconsider taking investors at all. For founders who are more guarded by nature, a tight confidentiality obligation tied to those information rights is a reasonable compromise.

This chapter reframes information rights as an operational and cultural decision rather than only a legal restriction. It links back to earlier lessons about the term sheet (what gets written into the term sheet is what governs the relationship) and the procedural warnings about timing and exclusivity: pay attention to when information rights kick in, who receives the information, and under what confidentiality protections. In short, the chapter advances the practical founder’s perspective — negotiate scope, timing, frequency and protections for information rights consciously, because transparency is both a practical tool for investor alignment and a contractual commitment that shapes governance going forward.
main_topics: whether and how to grant information rights
operational transparency vs. secrecy
using confidentiality to protect sensitive data
practical negotiation levers (scope, frequency, recipients)
relationship between disclosure obligations and governance

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

Don't focus much energy on registration rights. This is more about upside. The
world is good if you're going public.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 8 reframes the earlier clause-by-clause, lawyerly tour of the term sheet into the founder’s strategic vantage point: think about how each negotiated point affects the ultimate upside event — most commonly an IPO — rather than treating negotiation as an abstract legal exercise. Building on the ‘‘art of the term sheet’’ and the anatomy of standard provisions (Chapters 4–5) and the procedural warnings about exclusivity and timing (Chapter 6), the chapter urges founders to prioritize the provisions that materially influence public‑market attractiveness and future optionality. It stresses that many investor protections (registration rights included) only matter in certain endgames and should be weighed against the cost they impose on making the company a straightforward, marketable public equity story.

The chapter then translates those priorities into practical negotiating instincts: structure for a clean, simple capital table; cap or limit liquidation preferences and participation that can poison public comparability; avoid complex anti‑dilution hooks that create future hostage situations; and think early about governance and board composition that will both satisfy sophisticated public investors and preserve founder credibility. Registration rights are noted but downplayed: they only create value if the company goes public, so the entrepreneur’s focus should be on preserving the attributes that make an IPO feasible and attractive — signaling, simplicity, aligned incentives, and timely process — rather than over‑negotiating protections that are primarily contractual afterthoughts.
main_topics: shifting negotiation focus from lawyerly clauses to upside outcomes
how term sheet provisions affect IPO attractiveness
practical clause priorities for founders
minimizing contractual friction that deters public investors
timing, process and preparatory governance

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

The right of first refusal is not a big deal, and in some cases it's good for you.
But make sure you define what a major investor is and give this only to them. At
a minimum, you can make sure that shareholders get this right only if they play
in subsequent rounds.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter brings the founder's practical view to a specific, frequently used term-sheet feature: the restriction on sales or right of first refusal (ROFR) on common stock. Building on the earlier technical walk-through of term sheet clauses, the chapter explains that ROFR on common is usually benign and often beneficial — it helps the company control who owns its shares while allowing orderly secondary transfers. The authors recommend placing the ROFR in the bylaws (rather than scattering it across option agreements and plans) to keep it centralized and hard to miss. They also note how the rise of secondary markets and lengthening liquidity timelines has increased both the frequency of private share transfers and the importance of having a clear ROFR regime.

Practically, the chapter advises founders to be precise about who gets ROFR rights: define "major investors" and consider limiting ROFR to investors who continue to participate in subsequent financing rounds. This narrows who can block or buy off transfers and aligns transfer control with parties who have an ongoing stake in the company. Finally, the chapter emphasizes the regulatory backdrop — heightened SEC attention to private ownership and transfers — making ROFR not only a governance convenience but a protective measure to keep the shareholder base manageable and transparent.

Practical implementation (prefer bylaws)
Evolving private secondary markets and effects on transfers
Limiting ROFR to active/major investors
Regulatory considerations

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

A proprietary information and inventions agreement clause is good for the com-
pany. You should have all employees, including founders, sign something like
this before you do an outside venture financing. If someone on the team needs
a specific carve-out for work in progress that is unrelated to the business, you
and your investors should be willing to grant it.
chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter grounds the prior, lawyerly walk-through in the entrepreneur’s practical needs. It reiterates that a proprietary information and inventions agreement (PIIA) is a standard and necessary protection for the company — and that all employees, including founders, should sign one before an outside financing. The chapter stresses pragmatism: if a founder has unrelated work in progress, reasonable carve-outs can and should be negotiated rather than resisted reflexively. Getting assignment and confidentiality paperwork in place early protects the company and clears title to the technology that investors will underwrite.

The chapter also turns to liquidity and co-sale mechanics from the founder’s seat. While investors will almost always insist on co-sale rights, founders can and should ask for a sensible floor that permits small personal sales (for example, to buy a house) without investor veto. The text distinguishes a legitimate right of first refusal based on a bona fide outside offer valuation from an effective exclusion that nullifies a founder’s ability to sell. The practical takeaway: accept core investor protections where necessary, but negotiate limited exceptions and valuation mechanics so everyday founder needs aren’t unduly blocked.
key_concepts: Founder liquidity needs vs investor protections
main_topics: Employee/founder IP agreements before financing
Negotiating carve-outs for unrelated projects
Managing co-sale clauses to allow small founder sales
Distinguishing real ROFRs from de facto exclusions
Practical tradeoffs between legal protection and founder flexibility

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Entrepreneur's Perspective

If you can't agree to a founders' activities clause, don't look for professional
VC financing. Or you can negotiate a very specific carve-out, and expect other
consequences in your terms (e.g., vesting and IP rights).
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 11 continues the shift from clause-by-clause legalism to the entrepreneur’s practical vantage, building on the strategic framing introduced earlier (Chapter 8) and the practical protections discussed in Chapters 9–10. It opens with a blunt warning: if you cannot accept a founders’ activities clause you should not pursue professional VC financing — or be prepared to negotiate a tightly limited carve-out and to accept compensating consequences (for example, accelerated vesting or altered IP rights). The chapter then walks through three routine term-sheet provisions entrepreneurs should understand and generally accept: the no-shop agreement, indemnification for directors and investors, and the assignment clause for investors.

The no-shop is described as the investor’s demand for exclusivity while a deal is being closed — “serial monogamy” — and is best handled practically rather than adversarially: bound it by a short, defined time window (commonly 45–60 days, sometimes 30), and use it as a two-way commitment to gauge the VC’s seriousness. Real-world examples show that the clause is often irrelevant in practice when parties behave in good faith, but it can matter in edge cases. Indemnification is presented as largely non-negotiable in modern financings: companies are expected to limit director liability and to indemnify directors and investors, and to obtain D&O insurance as needed to attract outside board members. Finally, the assignment clause grants VCs the operational flexibility to transfer holdings among affiliated funds, provided transferees agree to be bound by the original financing agreements — and founders should guard against any loophole that would permit assignment without imposing the same obligations on the transferee.
main_topics: Practical negotiation priorities for entrepreneurs
How term-sheet clauses affect closing and exit timing
Risk allocation (liability and governance)
Investor operational flexibility vs. founder protections

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
The Capitalization Table N. ow that we've worked through all of the specific clauses in the term sheet, let's go through how a typical capitalization table (cap table) works. A term sheet will almost always contain a summary cap table, which we describe in this chapter. You, your prospective investors, or occasionally your lawyers will generate a more detailed cap table. The cap table summarizes who owns what part of the company before and after the financing. This is one area that some founders, especially those who have not been exposed in the past to cap table math, are often uncomfortable with. It's extremely important for founders to understand exactly who owns what part of a company and what the implications are in a potential funding round. Normally when you initially set up the company, 100% will be allocated to the founders and employees, with a specific number of shares allocated to each individual. The question "What will I own if a venture capitalist invests X in my company at a Y valuation?" is rarely simple. To answer it, you need to be able to generate a cap table to truly analyze the deal presented by a particular term sheet. Following is a model to work from with a typical example. Let's assume the following: 2 million shares held by founders before the VC invests $10 million pre-money valuation $5 million investment by the VC In this example, the post-money valuation is $15 million ($10 mil- lion pre-money + $5 million investment). Consequently, the VCs own 33.33% of the company after the financing ($5 million invest- ment/$15 million post-money valuation). This should be pretty straightforward so far. Now, assume the term sheet includes a new employee option pool of 20% on a post-money basis. Remember that this means that after the financing, there will be an unallocated option pool equal to 20% of the company. Although the post-money valuation remains the same ($15 mil- lion), the requirement for a 20% option pool will have a significant impact on the ownership of the founders. Per the cap table, you can see how we calculate the percentage ownership for each class of owner, along with the price per share of the preferred stock. To start, we've filled in the known numbers and now have to solve for the unknowns (A, B, C, D, and E). First, let's solve for A, the founders' ownership percentage: A = 100% minus the VC percentage minus the employee pool percent- age, or 100% - 33.33% - 20% = 46.67%. Given that we know that the 2 million founders' shares represent 46.67% of the company, we can determine that the total shares outstanding (E = 2 million/ 0.4667) are 4,285,408. Now, if there are 4,285,408 shares outstanding, deter- mining the number of shares in the employee pool becomes B = E *0.20 or 857,081. The same math applies for C, the number of shares of preferred stock the VCs have. C = E * 0.3333 or 1,428,326. Since $5 million bought 1,428,326 shares of preferred stock, then the price per share of preferred stock (D = $5 million/1,428,326) is $3.50 per share. Finally, always check your calculation. Since we know we have a $10 million pre-money valuation, then the shares prior to the financ- ing (2 million founders' shares plus the 20% option pool) times the price per share should equal $10 million. If you do this math, you'll
Example Capitalization Table
Class Shares Preferred Price Valuation Percentage
Founders 2,000,000 A
Employee pool B 20%
Venture investors C D $5,000,000 33.33%
Total E D $15,000,000 100%
see that (2 million + 857,081) * $3.50 = $9,999,783.50. Oops, we are off by $216.50, which represents 62 shares (well, 61.857 shares). While this is close enough for an example, it's not close enough for most VCs, or for most lawyers for that matter. And it shouldn't be close enough for you. That's why most cap tables have two addi- tional significant digits (or fractional shares)-the rounding to the nearest share doesn't happen during intermediate steps but only at the very end. As the entrepreneur, you shouldn't blindly rely on legal counsel to generate these documents. There are a lot of good lawyers out there with poor math skills, and the cap table can get messed up when left in the hands of the lawyers. Although some get it right, it's your responsibility as the entrepreneur to make sure you understand your cap table. This will be especially helpful at times when you want to expand the employee option pool and you are eloquent in front of your board of directors explaining the ramifications.
chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 12 moves from clause-level term sheet mechanics (Chapters 9–11) to the practical arithmetic that shows who actually owns the company: the capitalization table. It explains that a term sheet will almost always include a summary cap table and that founders must be able to generate and validate a more detailed cap table themselves. Using a concrete numerical example (2,000,000 founder shares, $10M pre-money, $5M investment, 20% post-money option pool), the chapter demonstrates how pre- and post-money valuations determine ownership percentages, how to solve for total shares outstanding and price per preferred share, and how a post-money option pool can materially dilute founders. It also highlights the real-world need for precision (fractional shares and extra significant digits) and warns founders not to blindly rely on lawyers for the math.

This chapter builds on earlier themes: the term sheet’s economic mechanics (Chapter 9) and the entrepreneur’s responsibility to protect company interests (Chapters 10–11). It shifts the conversation from legal language to arithmetic consequences—showing how a seemingly innocuous clause like a post-money 20% option pool reduces founder ownership (46.67% in the example) and establishes the VC stake (33.33%). The chapter’s practical takeaways are clear: understand the cap table, check the algebra, ensure rounding only happens at the end, and be prepared to explain dilution and option-pool expansions to investors and the board.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Convertible Debt

I,
n the past few chapters we've gone through, in detail, the terms
in a typical venture capital equity financing. However, there is one
other type of financing, often used at the seed stage, called a con-
vertible debt financing. In fact, many angel investors will invest only
with this structure.

Convertible debt is just that: debt. It's a loan. The loan will con-
vert to equity (preferred stock, usually) at such time as another
round is raised. The conversion usually includes some sort of dis-
count on the price to the future round.

For example, assume you raise $500,000 in convertible debt
from angels with a 20% discount to the next round, and six months
later a venture capitalist (VC) offers to lead a Series A round of a
$1 million investment at $1 a share. Your financing will actually be
for $1.5 million total, although the VCs will get 1 million Series A
shares ($1 million at $1 per share) and the angels will get 625,000
Series A shares ($500,000 at $0.80 per share). The discount is appro-
priate, as your early investors want some reward for investing before
the full Series A financing round comes together.

In this chapter, we cover the arguments for and against using
convertible debt. We then go through the terms in a convertible
debt deal, including the discount, valuation caps, interest rate, con-
version mechanics, conversion in a sale of the company, warrants,
and other terms. We briefly cover the differences between early-stage
and late-stage dynamics and finish up with an example of when con-
vertible debt could be dangerous to use.

chapter_summaries.summary:
Chapter 13 introduces convertible debt (convertible notes) as a common seed-stage financing alternative to priced equity rounds and explains the practical economics, mechanics, and trade-offs entrepreneurs must understand. Building on earlier term-sheet and cap-table discussions, the chapter defines the basic note structure (a loan that converts into preferred stock at the next qualified financing), the typical discount to the next round, and the investor-friendly valuation cap that limits the conversion price when the next round is priced very high. It also walks through conversion mechanics (qualified financing thresholds, maturity dates, automatic vs. voluntary conversion), amendment/consent thresholds among noteholders, and the risks when notes don’t convert on schedule (debt remaining on the cap table and potential creditor leverage).

The chapter then covers less obvious features: warrants as an alternative form of discount (their valuation, exercise price, term, merger treatment, and original issue discount/accounting consequences), differences in how convertible debt has been used as bridge financings versus modern seed-stage use (main driver: avoidance of setting valuation), and SAFE/KISS alternatives that attempt to capture advantages of notes without debt dynamics (no interest, often no maturity). Practical entrepreneurial advice includes negotiating a reasonable conversion horizon (and forced conversion), preferring a floor (cap) structured thoughtfully, avoiding double-dipping (discount plus warrants), keeping seed terms confidential when possible, and modeling how notes affect the cap table and future VC negotiations.

chapter_summaries.chapter_title:
Legal Things Every Entrepreneur Should Know

T.
here are a few legal issues that we've seen consistently become
hurdles for entrepreneurs and their lawyers. While in some cases
they will simply be a hassle to clean up in a financing or an exit,
they often have meaningful financial implications for the company
and, in the worst case, can seriously damage the value of your busi-
ness. We aren't your lawyers or giving you legal advice here (our
lawyers made us write that), but we encourage you to understand
these issues rather than just assume that your lawyer got them right.

If you want to read the best book ever written on legal issues that
face entrepreneurs, get the book The Entrepreneur's Guide to Business
Law, Fourth Edition, by Constance Bagley and Craig Dauchy (South-
Western, 2012). It is written for entrepreneurs, not lawyers, so it's easily
digestible and is the best legal resource we know for entrepreneurs.
chapter_summaries.summary: Chapter 14 is a pragmatic checklist of legal pitfalls that repeatedly trip up entrepreneurs and can materially affect financings and exits. Building on the economic and term-sheet mechanics from earlier chapters, the authors shift focus from negotiated clauses to three practical legal areas every founder must proactively manage: employment issues (hiring, at-will status, severance and the risk of employment litigation), choice of corporate entity (C Corp vs S Corp vs LLC and the implication for fundraising, taxes, and option grants), and the critical tax filing known as the 83(b) election (a time‑sensitive step that, if missed, can eliminate capital gains treatment and dramatically increase taxes). The chapter emphasizes that these are not abstract legal niceties — mistakes are often irreversible or expensive to fix during a financing or sale — and urges entrepreneurs to understand them rather than assume their lawyer handled them correctly.

chapter_summaries.summary:
This chapter shifts focus from the transactional mechanics of funding (covered in earlier chapters on cap tables, convertible notes, and legal pitfalls) to the upstream question of why startup activity clusters in some places and not others. It reviews three academic frameworks (economic agglomeration/external economies, sociological, and geographical explanations) that explain the "spikiness" of innovation, and then introduces a fourth, practice-driven framework — the Boulder Thesis — drawn from the authors' local experience. The Boulder Thesis asserts that vibrant startup communities are entrepreneur-led, require long-term commitment, must be inclusive, and need continual activities that engage the whole entrepreneurial stack.

Building on the practical tools founders learned previously (how to structure equity, convertible instruments, and avoid legal traps), the chapter explains why community conditions matter for deploying those tools successfully. A deep, inclusive ecosystem supplies the specialized suppliers, mentors, investors, and talent that make cap tables meaningful, convertible-note markets viable, and legal compliance accessible. The chapter stresses the long horizon required (a forward-looking ~20-year commitment), the importance of activity-based engagement (hackathons, accelerators, meetups), and tolerance for iterative failure in community programming as essential to sustained entrepreneurial success.
main_topics: Why startup communities cluster
Four frameworks explaining regional entrepreneurial advantage
Principles for building a vibrant startup community
Role of long-term leadership and commitment
Designing inclusive, ongoing activities to engage all stakeholders
